channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on the Boston Blasts
item.description: The Lede is following the aftermath of Monday’s deadly explosions at the Boston Marathon, which killed three and injured more than 170 on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A screenshot from a WBZ Boston broadcast, showing an image of the boat authorities believe the suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings was hiding in late Friday.

item.title: Quake Kills Dozens in China, and Hundreds Are Injured
item.description: The earthquake struck the western region of Sichuan province, where a previous quake killed 70,000 people.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Musharraf Is Arrested and Held in Pakistan
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, a former military leader in Pakistan, was arrested and moved into police custody — an unprecedented move in a country where the military has held sway for decades.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A banner depicting Pervez Musharraf served as a curtain in a makeshift home on the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan.

item.title: State Dept. Sees Little Progress on Global Human Rights
item.description: The State Department’s annual report on human rights practices cited continuing problems in Iran, Russia and China, but highlighted some bright spots in Myanmar and Georgia.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: Earthquake in China Is Said to Kill 32
item.description: A Communist Party official said that the earthquake that hit China’s Sichuan provinces left at least 32 people dead and injured more than 600.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Jury Cites Poor Medical Care in Death of Indian Woman in Ireland
item.description: The jury ruled that Savita Halappanavar died from “medical misadventure” after the hospital staff refused to perform an abortion when she developed blood poisoning.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Justin Trudeau in His Father’s Footsteps, Only More Uphill
item.description: Justin Trudeau became the leader of the Liberal Party in Canada on Sunday, 45 years after his father, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, claimed a similar victory. But the parallels may end there.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: “I knew that the challenge I would be facing all my life would be having people think that I expected anything to be handed to me in politics because of my last name.”

item.title: New Venezuela President Sworn In, but Vote to Be Audited
item.description: Nicolás Maduro won the election by a narrow margin, but his opponent, Henrique Capriles Radonski, has refused to recognize the result.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro, center left, was sworn in on Friday as president of Venezuela before the National Assembly in Caracas.

item.title: More U.S. Aid to Syria’s Rebels, With Conditions
item.description: Delivery of new nonlethal aid approved by President Obama will hinge in part on promises by the opposition to protect minorities and to abide by the rule of law, according to an official.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Study Finds Sharp Rise in Attacks by Afghan Taliban
item.description: It is unclear whether militants are able to mount an all-out attempt to test the Afghan security forces as they take over from withdrawing allies.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghanistan Army soldiers with American soldiers in Paktia Province last Sunday. Afghan forces are taking over security duties.

item.title: Language Programs Flower in Utah’s Schools
item.description: Utah, with a history of missionary work, hopes to create a bilingual work force, in part to lure international businesses.
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
item.dc:creator: By JACK HEALY
item.media:credit: Michael Friberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lily Buneo, teaching Portuguese at Lakeview Elementary in Provo, Utah.

item.title: Serbia and Kosovo Reach Deal on Power-Sharing
item.description: The accord over municipalities in Kosovo’s Serb-majority north paves the way for Kosovo and Serbia to pursue membership in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Catherine Ashton, of the European Union, with the Serbian leader Ivica Dacic, left, and Hashim Thaci of Kosovo on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sweet 16, Plus 100 More
item.description: The world’s oldest living person, Jiroemon Kimura, celebrated his 116th birthday on Friday with congratulations from around the world.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: China’s North Korea Envoy to Visit Washington
item.description: The visit comes after Secretary of State John Kerry said in Beijing last week that China could play a vital role in helping rid North Korea of its nuclear weapons.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and BREE FENG

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Clashes Erupt Over Courts in Egypt
item.description: Supporters and opponents of Egypt’s Islamist president clashed near Tahrir Square in Cairo on Friday at an Islamist rally demanding a purge of the judiciary.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: More U.S. Aid to Syria’s Rebels, With Conditions
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry planned to meet with the opposition in Istanbul to discuss what support the United States would offer and what would be expected.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Leftist Group Suspended
item.description: Russian prosecutors suspended a leftist opposition group for three months in what critics of President Vladimir V. Putin say is an intensifying crackdown on dissent sponsored by the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canadian Accused in Plot to Help Qaddafi’s Son Is Released
item.description: A Canadian woman charged with plotting to smuggle Saadi el-Qaddafi, a son of the former Libyan dictator, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, into Mexico was released from prison.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: U.N. Peacekeeper Is Killed in Sudan
item.description: The United Nations said that a Nigerian peacekeeper in the Sudanese state of East Darfur was shot dead and two others were wounded Friday in an attack by gunmen.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Judge Rejects Annulment of Ex-Dictator’s Guatemala Trial
item.description: The confusion surrounding the genocide trial of Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt highlighted the polarized emotions raised by a month of testimony about the bloodiest chapter in the country’s long civil war.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Efraín Ríos Montt, in glasses, after a hearing on Friday during his trial on genocide charges in Guatemala City. A judge is trying to have the case retried.

item.title: Spectator Interrupt’s Nicolás Maduro During Inaugural Address
item.description: A man pushed Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s new president, away from the microphone as he delivered his inaugural address.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A red-jacketed man pushed Nicolás Maduro, center right, away from the microphone as he delivered his inaugural address in Caracas on Friday.

item.title: Son-in-Law of Bin Laden Denied More Phone Calls
item.description: Lawyers for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, said one monthly phone call was not sufficient to remain in contact with family members who live in three different countries.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Using the Law to Crack the Glass Ceiling
item.description: Much of Europe relies on voluntary action by companies to get more women into boardrooms. But with the number of women executives continuing to lag, there is growing pressure for legislation. Join the conversation: Do you think governments should pass laws stipulating how many women are on a corporation’s board?
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Americans Learn of Chechnya
item.description: Marcus Mabry, Rendezvous’s editor, speaks to Clifford J. Levy, the former Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times, about the Chechen origins of the suspected Boston Marathon bombers,Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Ode to Pasta, and to the Pluck of the Italian Family Business
item.description: A show this week to honor the pasta maker Pietro Barilla, who would have turned 100 on Tuesday, was a feel-good moment for a country whose businesses are feeling bad.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
